chapter.title: Logging In to lx Branded Zones (Tasks)

highlights.para: This chapter provides the following information:

listitem.para: Completing the internal configuration of an installed lx branded zone
Logging into the zone from the global zone
Using the zonename command to print the name of the current zone

sect1.title: zlogin Command Overview
sect1.para: The zlogin command is used to log in from the global zone to any zone that is in the running state or the ready state.

note.para: Only the zlogin command with the C option can be used to log in to a zone that is not in the running state.

sect1.para: Unless the C option is used to connect to the zone console, logging in to a zone using zlogin starts a new task. A task cannot span two zones.

As described in How to Use Non-Interactive Mode to Access an lx Branded Zone, you can use the zlogin command in non-interactive mode by supplying a command to run inside a zone. However, the command or any files the command acts upon cannot reside on NFS. The command will fail if any of its open files or any portion of its address space resides on NFS. The address space includes the command executable itself and the command's linked libraries.
The zlogin command can only be used by the global administrator operating in the global zone. See the zlogin1 man page for more information.

sect1.title: lx Branded Zone Login Methods
sect1.para: An overview of zone console and user login methods is provided in Non-Global Zone Login Methods.

The failsafe mode is used when a login problem occurs that prevents you from using the zlogin command or the zlogin command with the C option to access the zone. This mode is described in Failsafe Mode
Information on remote login zone is provided in Remote Login

Interactive mode allocates a new pseudo-terminal for use inside the zone. Non-interactive mode is used to run shell-scripts which administer the zone. See Interactive and Non-Interactive Modes for more information.

sect1.title: Login Procedures for Branded Zones (Task Map)

entry.para: You can log into a zone through the console, by using interactive mode to allocate a pseudo-terminal, or by supplying a command to be run in the zone. Supplying a command to be run does not allocate a pseudo-terminal. You can also log in by using failsafe mode when a connection to the zone is denied.

sect1.title: Logging In to an lx Branded Zone
sect1.para: Use the zlogin command to log in from the global zone to any zone that is running or in the ready state. See the zlogin1 man page for more information.
You can log in to a zone in various ways, as described in the following procedures. You can also log in remotely, as described in Remote Login.

task.title: How to Log In to the lx Branded Zone Console

tasksummary.para: You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Use the zlogin command with the C option and the name of the zone, for example, lx-zone.
step.screen: global# zlogin -C lx-zone [Connected to zone 'lx-zone' console]

note.para: If you start the zlogin session immediately after issuing the zoneadm boot command, boot messages from the zone will display:
note.screen: INIT: version 2.85 booting Welcome to CentOS Press 'I' to enter interactive startup. Configuring kernel parameters: [ OK ] Setting hostname lx-zone: [ OK ] [...] CentOS release 3.6 (Final) Kernel 2.4.21 on an i686

step.para: When the zone console displays, log in as root, press Return, and type the root password when prompted.

note.para: Recall that the root (superuser) password is root when the zone is installed from the Sun tarball. The root (superuser) password is unset (blank) when the zone is installed from ISO images or a CD.

task.title: How to Use Interactive Mode to Access a Branded Zone

tasksummary.para: In interactive mode, a new pseudo-terminal is allocated for use inside the zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, log in to the zone, for example, lx-zone.
Information similar to the following will display:
step.screen: [Connected to zone 'lx-zone' pts/2] Last login: Wed Jul 3 16:25:00 on console Sun Microsystems Inc. SunOS 5.10 Generic July 2006

step.para: Type exit to close the connection.
You will see a message similar to the following:

task.title: How to Verify the Running Environment

tasksummary.para: You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Log in to the zone, for example, lx-zone.
Verify that you are running in a Linux environment under the Solaris Operating System.
You will see a display similar to the following:
step.screen: Linux myzone 2.4.21 BrandZ fake linux i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux

task.title: How to Use Non-Interactive Mode to Access an lx Branded Zone

tasksummary.para: Non-interactive mode is enabled when the user supplies a command to be run inside the zone. Non-interactive mode does not allocate a new pseudo-terminal.
Note that the command or any files that the command acts upon cannot reside on NFS.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, log in to the lx-zone zone and supply a command name.
Replace command with the name of the command to be run inside the zone.

example.title: Using the Command uptime in the Zone lx_master
example.screen: global# zlogin lx_master uptime 21:16:01 up 2:39, 0 users, load average: 0.19, 0.13, 0.11 fireball#

task.title: How to Use Failsafe Mode to Enter an lx Branded Zone

tasksummary.para: When a connection to the zone is denied, the zlogin command can be used with the S option to enter a minimal environment in the zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
From the global zone, use the zlogin command with the S option to access the zone, for example, lx-zone.

task.title: How to Use zlogin to Shut Down an lx Branded Zone

note.para: Running init 0 in the global zone to cleanly shut down a Solaris system also runs init 0 in each of the non-global zones on the system. Note that init 0 does not warn local and remote users to log off before the system is taken down.

tasksummary.para: Use this procedure to cleanly shut down a zone. To halt a zone without running shutdown scripts, see How to Halt a Zone.
You must be the global administrator in the global zone to perform this procedure.

step.para: Become superuser, or assume the Primary Administrator role.
To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Using the Solaris Management Tools With RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Log in to the zone to be shut down, for example, lx-zone, and specify shutdown as the name of the utility and init 0 as the state.
Your site might have its own shutdown script, tailored for your specific environment.

taskrelated-custom.title: Using shutdown in Non-Interactive Mode
taskrelated-custom.para: You cannot use the shutdown command in non-interactive mode to place the zone in single—user state at this time. See 6214427 for more information.
You can use an interactive login as described in How to Use Interactive Mode to Access a Branded Zone.
